summary: This document is an email chain from August 13-14, 2019, between federal prosecutors discussing evidence and strategy in the Jeffrey Epstein case. The emails focus on the evidence for trafficking offenses at Epstein's Florida and Virgin Islands properties, victim cooperation, and potential forfeiture actions and their impact on upcoming civil lawsuits.

connections.description: They are engaged in a professional email exchange discussing legal strategy and evidence assessment in the Epstein case.

events.title: Email discussion on evidence and forfeiture
events.description: Prosecutors exchange emails to clarify the state of evidence regarding trafficking offenses at Epstein's Florida and Virgin Islands properties and discuss forfeiture options.

events.title: New York State look-back law takes effect
events.description: Mention that the New York State look-back law re-opens the statute of limitations for sex crimes without limitation, prompting multiple attorneys to plan filing civil lawsuits starting on this date.

keyFacts: Prosecutors state the only evidence of trafficking offenses at Epstein's Florida property involves victims identified in the original Florida investigation.
Prosecutors note they do not presently have evidence of trafficking offenses involving the Virgin Islands property, pending search warrant results.
Multiple attorneys planned to file civil lawsuits on behalf of clients starting August 14, 2019, when New York's look-back law reopened the statute of limitations for sex crimes.
The email chain discusses the need to understand how a government forfeiture action might affect pending civil claims from victims.
The correspondence indicates internal coordination among prosecutors regarding evidence assessment and legal strategy ahead of potential forfeiture actions.
